hints.content: Start by understanding the definitions of low score and high score. The low score is the minimum absolute difference between any two integers in the array, while the high score is the maximum absolute difference.
To calculate the low score, you can sort the array first. The minimum absolute difference will be between two adjacent elements after sorting.
For the high score, you can simply find the difference between the maximum and minimum elements in the array. This is straightforward: `high_score = max(nums) - min(nums)`.
Consider how changing two elements can affect both the low and high scores. Changing elements can potentially reduce the high score and/or eliminate the low score.
Think about edge cases. For example, if all elements in the array are the same, what would the scores be? How would changing any two elements affect the outcome?
When changing two elements, you might want to set them both to the same value, which could help in minimizing the low score. What value would you choose?
Explore the idea of setting the two elements you change to either the minimum or maximum value of the array. How would that impact the scores?
After changing two elements, you will need to recalculate both the low and high scores. Make sure your logic accounts for these changes correctly.
Consider the implications of changing two elements to the same value versus changing them to different values. How does each approach affect the scores?

To find the minimum score after changing two elements, you will need to evaluate several scenarios. Think about how you can systematically test different pairs of changes to find the optimal solution.

questionNotes: You need to return the minimum score after changing exactly two elements.
Consider both the low score and high score when calculating the final result.
